body:
Strangely I had to 
`user._password = generate_password_hash("$3", 12).decode('utf-8')`
@Fokko any remarks on this PR?
@fokko I've added the autoclass documentation

From https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/json_api/v1/objects/copy:

>Use the copy method to copy between objects in the same location and storage class. When copying objects across locations or storage classes it's sometimes possible to use the copy method, but we recommend using the rewrite method instead because if the source and destination are in different locations or storage classes the copy method calls the rewrite method exactly once behind the scenes. The larger the object the more likely that multiple rewrite calls will be needed to complete the operation. If the single rewrite call made by copy doesn't complete the operation it will result in a Deadline exceeded error.

I am curious to know the use of `copy` method in presence of `rewrite` method. @fenglu-g  @tswast
Thanks for the review @Fokko, replaced mock tests with actual ones.
Rewrite could require multiple API calls for large files. https://cloud.google.com/storage/docs/json_api/v1/objects/rewrite
@tswast But `copy` won't work for largr files over 5 TB I suppose?

CI failures are caused by environmental issues, not by tests themselves.
This build(https://travis-ci.org/apache/incubator-airflow/builds/389515754) shows all the tests pass and flake8 fail to run.

LGTM
The CI link points to a different commit though, I'll wait for travis to clear this commit and merge.
Thanks Max @mistercrunch , it seems the CI is not very stable(fail on certain ORM, but succeed on the others). I trigger the CI again and hopefully it could clear this time.

CI passed on my TravisCI: https://travis-ci.org/milton0825/incubator-airflow/builds/389830276
Looks like CI is quite unstable right now.
PTAL @Fokko @mistercrunch @jgao54

@yrqls21 I think I'm done with the review here.
@Fokko can you chime in with your opinion about the changes to the bash and python ops? Do they belong here?

@yrqls21 I don't have merge power :)

Anyhow: we're waiting on a couple of PyHive improvements (if they don't happen by next week we'll probably fork). So: let's go ahead with your PR first, I'll rebase against master later.

@gglanzani SGTM, thank you. Let me know if you have more comments on my PR, plan to merge it tomorrow with help from @aoen 

BTW, would you actually elaborate a bit on exactly what improvementse we're expecting on PyHive please?
👍 This PR fixed my problem, why not been merged yet? we need it !

@bolkedebruin @Fokko  PTAL. this bug was introduced from [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3257/commits/3450f526cec894cc7beceeae18f9d54cb2ae7520) , and there is a fix [here](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3258/commits/bf244701e35e973c6b7ee2ee41e5524ceafeed30) , which didn't fix it at all, it runs correctly after I fix it in the PR.
Thanks @feng-tao . I will review and test this by end of tomorrow

@tswast @fenglu-g Based on the thread, I am still unable to figure out the use of `copy` method while `rewrite` method exist. I am sure there must be some reason of having 2 separate methods `copy` and `rewrite`. And what do you think about the change in this PR?
Thanks, all merged to master now.

`rewrite` is the more general method, yes. The `copy` method is mostly a helper method for those using the API directly, a library such as this one should probably always use `rewrite`.

I see that the hook does loop with `rewrite` until the copy is complete, so this change should work as intended.

https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/df05546f8d4676ff3651e6a4c093ad068c7f5bbc/airflow/contrib/hooks/gcs_hook.py#L125-L140
Thanks @ashb
Cool. 👍 understood. Thanks @tswast
LGTM
Thank you @torkjel for your contribution.

Taken care of the issues pointed out, _check_input can't be pushed to a static method, or to the hook since what it checks is unique depending on operator. 
As for the exception, I've made it more apparent what happens in the docs, an exception is thrown if JSON parsing goes wrong.

Thanks
Thanks @kaxil
Trying to think whether % DAG Runs is very useful. Could be cool to show some sort of matrix task/time (closer to what the tree view looks like) instead.
Cool feature!

@mistercrunch thanks for the comment. I am more inclined to provide a singe line progress bar to show users the progress of the whole backfill and I think that `finished DAG runs/ total DAG runs` should be representative. Can you explain a bit on why % DAG runs is not useful?

Regarding to showing task/time (tree view), I am worried that if the DAG contains too many operators, there will be no room on console to show all tasks.

@roc I’ll have a look. But can you please stop closing/opening the Pr for the sake trying it? Apache Infra has asked us not to do this.
@bolkedebruin  OK, I was trying to retrigger the CI because of the CI failure  😅

I like it. Maybe you could use the approach Spark takes for this: show dagruns and amount of tasks? I do wonder how it behaves in logging as updateing the CLi will most likely cause a lot of stdout traffic polluting the log. Basically I think it should only do this when you run the backfill by hand?

hi @kaxil , I heard from @DanSedov privately that he expected the DataProc new release to contain a high-level error message in the top level of the response, but that the failure information for individual jobs will likely remain in the metadata.  In this case, a small change to my PR would allow us to propagate job-specific failure messages into the Airflow task logs, which I think would be useful (the original PR already does this, but only when the top-level error field is not filled).  What do you guys think about this?


I definitely think that the job-specific message would be useful. Is the new release out for Dataproc? If not, lets wait for it and then update the PR accordingly.
Thanks for this. This is certainly going to be very helpful.
it seems that the CI failure was not related
@imroc Please run this on your own Travis since Apache is paying for the Travis hours. Please do the retries on your own Travis and link the successful build.
Nice one
Main thing is that we need to split this into multiple PR's, the stuff for the Bash and Python operator needs to be checked very thoroughly.

@Fokko Sure I agree the situation in bash operator is a bit independent and I'm fine opening another PR just for the change of behavior on how do we get AIRFLOW_HOME value--I can elaborate more on why I chose to do that in the PR. But for the python operator part, I feel opening another PR making changes to provide Airflow context in hive is missing some context and thus belongs to this PR more--updating the env var mapping is quite safe and I don't this worth losing the context to create another PR for it.

Also, would you elaborate a bit more on what checks do you have in mind please?

Hopefully the PR https://github.com/dropbox/PyHive/pull/219 will be merged quickly and there will be a new release. This will make PyHive fully compatible with Airflow again since we're using SQLAlchemy 1.2.x in Airflow. I'm fine with merging this PR first and then do a quick follow up PR when the Dropbox PR has been merged.
The most important thing is that we don't change current behaviour, we can extend it, but it should be backwards compatible.

@imroc @Fokko @bolkedebruin @aoen PTAL, wanna get rid of those failed CI tests in my other PRs.

I'm only fixing the behavior change for db that does not support autocommit. But the PR I referred in the description had another change of behavior which is to change the default value of autocommit in the parameter. Would someone elaborate why do we want to change that please? I'm a bit worried about the performance implication from that change.

Hello @dimberman @milton0825 @rodrigc 

So, I managed to address a few outstanding issues with this build. Currently the tests are failing because master is broken though (test_check_operators was broken a few commits ago it seems). In the meantime, I think this is ready. I would love if you guys can try it out.

I'm concerned about documentation. A few days ago, Fokko introduced a little bit of documentation for [setting up a development environment using docker](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/commit/7db18183677d96e37f4671aa846815d3ecc7e58c). It only adds a section to use a docker container for dev mode, but it doesn't address the rest of the contributor's documentation, e.g:

* `./run_unit_tests.sh` is completely unusable
*  There are lots of integration tests in the test suite, which need a more comprehensive setup (MySQL, krb5 tests) than just a single docker container with python
* And of course, calling these "unit tests" is simply not accurate. These are integration tests as far as I can tell

For now, I decided to document [3 ways of setting up a dev environment](https://github.com/gerardo/incubator-airflow/blob/dd7a33ae4493b10332e76c85e000ea23274d89c8/CONTRIBUTING.md#development-and-testing). I think it might be better to just use this PR to address the CI environment, and create a separate one to document a development workflow properly.

What do you think?

@Fokko we actually don't export AIRFLOW_HOME value , we get and use its value from [these lines in configurations.py](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/master/airflow/configuration.py#L370-L373). That is actually where it make me uncomfortable with the previous behavior--if I have a `~/airflow.cfg` but not exporting AIRFLOW_HOME, and in my `~/airflow.cfg` I accidentally specified `airflow_home` as say `/srv/airflow`, then the subprocess will set AIRFLOW_HOME in configuration.py as `/srv/airflow` and use all the other configs in `/srv/airflow` to set up the Airflow env.

Hi @mchalek and @kaxil,
In the next few weeks Dataproc will begin to report shorter error messages for failed jobs. This will be of the form "Job step foo (jobId) failed". This replaces the current message "Job failed, see this log file gs:/...". User can always fetch the workflow (via gcloud command) to see all errors; and also fetch the job by id which is now captured in the message.

I feel strongly that Airflow should not _rewrite_ Dataproc error messages as this can only lead to confusion. I have no opinion or objection to collecting and _logging_ job errors, if that is useful.

Well, overall structure looks ok to me but I haven't used Azure a lot so wouldn't be able to review that.

My point was just that % DagRuns is a bit misleading. Say if you had only the last task of your backfill as depends_on_past=True and 95% of your tasks are done but none of the DagRuns have completed.

A per-task, per-state number may give a better picture. 

```
task_id  | in_scope | running | succes | failed |
-----------------------------------------------
foo         | 5             | 2            | 3            | 0        |
bar         | 5             | 2            | 2            | 1         |
...
```
I'm sure there are some great python CLI / tables lib out there

``` python 
hook = MySqlHook(mysql_conn_id='mysql_default', schema='test')
```
